item.Title: MacBook Pro 17" Models A1151 A1212 A1229 and A1261 Battery Connector Replacement
item.Category: MacBook Pro 17" Models A1151 A1212 A1229 and A1261

item.Text: use your fingers to push both battery release tabs away from the battery and lift the battery out of the computer .

item.Text_raw: Use your fingers to push both battery release tabs away from the battery and lift the battery out of the computer.

item.Text: remove the four identical phillips 3.4 mm screws from the memory door . these screws have 4 mm diameter heads rather than the 3 mm heads on the body screws .

item.Text_raw: Remove the four identical Phillips 3.4 mm screws from the memory door. These screws have 4 mm diameter heads rather than the 3 mm heads on the body screws.

item.Text: lift the memory door up enough to get a grip on it . and slide it toward you . pulling it away from the casing .

item.Text_raw: Lift the memory door up enough to get a grip on it, and slide it toward you, pulling it away from the casing.

item.Text: remove the three phillips screws in the battery compartment near the latch . apple was nice enough to tilt these screws at a slight angle to make them easier to remove . on the a1261 these screws have 4 mm diameter heads rather than the 3 mm heads on the body screws .

item.Text_raw: Remove the three Phillips screws in the battery compartment near the latch. Apple was nice enough to tilt these screws at a slight angle to make them easier to remove. On the A1261 these screws have 4 mm diameter heads rather than the 3 mm heads on the body screws.

item.Text: remove the following six screws .
two 14.5 mm t6 torx screws on either side of the ram slot .
four 3.4 mm phillips screws along the hinge .

item.Text_raw: Remove the following six screws: Two 14.5 mm T6 Torx screws on either side of the RAM slot. Four 3.4 mm Phillips screws along the hinge.

item.Text: remove the four 3.4 mm phillips screws on the port side of the computer .

item.Text_raw: Remove the four 3.4 mm Phillips screws on the port side of the computer.

item.Text: rotate the computer 90 degrees and remove the two phillips screws from the rear of the computer .

item.Text_raw: Rotate the computer 90 degrees and remove the two Phillips screws from the rear of the computer.

item.Text: rotate the computer 90 degrees again and remove the four phillips screws from the side of the computer .

item.Text_raw: Rotate the computer 90 degrees again and remove the four Phillips screws from the side of the computer.

item.Text: do not yank the upper case off quickly . the case is attached to the logic board via a ribbon cable .

lift up the back of the case and work your fingers along the sides . freeing the case as you go . once you have freed the sides . you may need to rock the case up and down to free the front of the upper case .

item.Text_raw: Do not yank the upper case off quickly. The case is attached to the logic board via a ribbon cable. Lift up the back of the case and work your fingers along the sides, freeing the case as you go. Once you have freed the sides, you may need to rock the case up and down to free the front of the upper case.

item.Text: disconnect the trackpad and keyboard ribbon cable from the logic board .
remove the upper case .

item.Text_raw: Disconnect the trackpad and keyboard ribbon cable from the logic board. Remove the upper case.

item.Text: disconnect the orange superdrive ribbon cable from the logic board . removing tape as necessary .

item.Text_raw: Disconnect the orange SuperDrive ribbon cable from the logic board, removing tape as necessary.

item.name: two black 4 mm t6 torx screws

item.Text: remove the following three screws .
two black 4 mm t6 torx screws on either side of the superdrive .
one 8.7 mm silver ( black in some models ) t6 torx screw at the back of the drive near the speaker .

item.Text_raw: Remove the following three screws: Two black 4 mm T6 Torx screws on either side of the SuperDrive. One 8.7 mm silver (black in some models) T6 Torx screw at the back of the drive near the speaker.

item.Text: use one hand to pull back the speaker cable and use your other hand to lift the optical drive up and out of the computer .
if you have a cd or any other object jammed in your optical drive . we have an guide .

item.Text_raw: Use one hand to pull back the speaker cable and use your other hand to lift the optical drive up and out of the computer. If you have a CD or any other object jammed in your optical drive, we have an [guide|772|optical drive repair guide].

item.Text: disconnect the ten indicated connectors from the logic board .
the connectors have different positions for the four macbook pro revisions covered by this guide . and their locations are highlighted in the three pictures on this step .

item.Text_raw: Disconnect the ten indicated connectors from the logic board. The connectors have different positions for the four MacBook Pro revisions covered by this guide, and their locations are highlighted in the three pictures on this step.

item.Text: rotate the large display data cable to the left and disconnect the small right thermal sensor cable beneath .
if you have the a1261 model . the right thermal sensor cable is located in between the right fan connector and display data cable .

item.Text_raw: Rotate the large display data cable to the left and disconnect the small right thermal sensor cable beneath. If you have the A1261 model, the right thermal sensor cable is located in between the right fan connector and display data cable.

item.name: single black 4 mm t6 torx screw

item.Text: remove the single black 4 mm t6 torx screw securing the clear plastic shield over the right ambient light sensor .
lift the clear plastic shield off the right ambient light sensor .

item.Text_raw: Remove the single black 4 mm T6 Torx screw securing the clear plastic shield over the right ambient light sensor. Lift the clear plastic shield off the right ambient light sensor.

item.Text: peel up the orange kapton tape securing the left thermal sensor cable to the logic board .
if you have a macbook pro 17 model a1229 . this is the middle thermal sensor .

item.Text_raw: Peel up the orange Kapton tape securing the left thermal sensor cable to the logic board. If you have a MacBook Pro 17" Model A1229, this is the middle thermal sensor.

item.name: two shanked 7.6 mm t6 torx screws

Step_level_parts.item: two shanked 7.6 mm t6 torx screws

item.Text: remove the following twelve screws .
seven 6.5 mm t6 torx screws .
two shanked 7.6 mm t6 torx screws securing the battery connector to the lower case .
three 7.8 mm t6 torx screws .

item.Text_raw: Remove the following twelve screws: Seven 6.5 mm T6 Torx screws. Two shanked 7.6 mm T6 Torx screws securing the battery connector to the lower case. Three 7.8 mm T6 Torx screws.

item.Text: lift up the left side of the logic board and disconnect the multi-colored power connector from the bottom of the board .

item.Text_raw: Lift up the left side of the logic board and disconnect the multi-colored power connector from the bottom of the board.

item.Text: grasp the logic board at the left side and at the thin section near the right fan . and rotate the logic board out of the lower case .

item.Text_raw: Grasp the logic board at the left side and at the thin section near the right fan, and rotate the logic board out of the lower case.

item.Text: if the right speaker assembly remains attached to the logic board . hold the logic board with one hand and slide the speaker up slightly to free it from the logic board .

to properly reassemble your macbook pro . you'll have to clean off and replace the thermal compound from the three chips on the underside of the logic board . use our guide to prepare the processor and heat sink surfaces .

item.Text_raw: If the right speaker assembly remains attached to the logic board, hold the logic board with one hand and slide the speaker up slightly to free it from the logic board. To properly reassemble your MacBook Pro, you'll have to clean off and replace the thermal compound from the three chips on the underside of the logic board. Use our [guide|744|Applying Thermal Paste Guide] to prepare the processor and heat sink surfaces.

item.Text: disconnect the multi-colored battery connector from the logic board .
to properly reassemble your macbook pro . you'll have to clean off and replace the thermal compound from the three chips shown here . use our guide to prepare the processor and heat sink surfaces .

item.Text_raw: Disconnect the multi-colored battery connector from the logic board. To properly reassemble your MacBook Pro, you'll have to clean off and replace the thermal compound from the three chips shown here. Use our [guide|744|Applying Thermal Paste Guide] to prepare the processor and heat sink surfaces.

lift up the back of the case and work your fingers along the sides . freeing the case as you go . once you have freed the sides . you may need to rock the case up and down to free the front of the upper case .

one 8.7 mm silver ( black in some models ) t6 torx screw at the back of the drive near the speaker .

if you have a cd or any other object jammed in your optical drive . we have an guide .

item.Text_raw: Lift the memory door up enough to get a grip on it, and slide it toward you, pulling it away from the casing.

item.Text_raw: Remove the two 2.8 mm Phillips screws in the battery compartment near the latch.

two 10 mm t6 torx screws on either side of the ram slot .
four 14.5 mm phillips screws along the hinge .

item.Text: do not yank the upper case off quickly . the case is attached to the logic board via a ribbon cable .

lift up at the rear of the case and work your fingers along the sides . freeing the case as you go . once you have freed the sides . you may need to rock the case up and down to free the front of the upper case ( there are some hidden plastic clips that need to be clicked off ) .

item.name: Eight 4.7 mm silver T6 Torx screws
One 6.2 mm black T6 Torx screw
Five 9.4 mm silver T6 Torx screws

Step_level_parts.item: five 9.4 mm silver t6 torx screws
eight 4.7 mm silver t6 torx screws
one 6.2 mm black t6 torx screw

item.Text: remove the following 15 screws .
one 4.4 mm black phillips screw to the right of the ram slot .
eight 4.7 mm silver t6 torx screws securing the logic board to the lower case .
one 6.2 mm black t6 torx screw on the right side of the left fan .
five 9.4 mm silver t6 torx screws securing the left and right fans .

item.Text_raw: Remove the following 15 screws: One 4.4 mm black Phillips screw to the right of the ram slot. Eight 4.7 mm silver T6 Torx screws securing the logic board to the lower case. One 6.2 mm black T6 Torx screw on the right side of the left fan. Five 9.4 mm silver T6 Torx screws securing the left and right fans.

item.Text: hold the logic board down with one hand and use your other hand to lift the left fan up from its housing . there is a piece of black tape securing the fan to the heat sink . carefully peel this tape up from the heat sink as you lift the fan up .
place the fan above the airport card . it is not necessary to remove the fan from the computer entirely .

item.Text_raw: Hold the logic board down with one hand and use your other hand to lift the left fan up from its housing. There is a piece of black tape securing the fan to the heat sink. Carefully peel this tape up from the heat sink as you lift the fan up. Place the fan above the Airport card. It is not necessary to remove the fan from the computer entirely.

item.Text: lift the right fan up and carefully peel up the tape securing the fan to the heat sink as you go .
remove the right fan from the computer .

item.Text_raw: Lift the right fan up and carefully peel up the tape securing the fan to the heat sink as you go. Remove the right fan from the computer.

item.Text: lift up the left side of the logic board and disconnect the gray and black power cable from the bottom of the board .

item.Text_raw: Lift up the left side of the logic board and disconnect the gray and black power cable from the bottom of the board.

item.Text: grasp the logic board at the left side and at the thin section . and rotate the logic board out of the lower case .
to properly reassemble your macbook pro . you'll have to clean off and replace the old thermal compound . use our guide to prepare the processor and heat sink surfaces .

item.Text_raw: Grasp the logic board at the left side and at the thin section, and rotate the logic board out of the lower case. To properly reassemble your MacBook Pro, you'll have to clean off and replace the old thermal compound. Use our [guide|744|Applying Thermal Paste Guide] to prepare the processor and heat sink surfaces.

item.Text: remove the two silver t6 torx screws securing the battery connector to the lower case .

item.Text_raw: Remove the two silver T6 Torx screws securing the battery connector to the lower case.

item.Text: disconnect the large gray and black battery connector cable from the left i/o board .

item.Text_raw: Disconnect the large gray and black battery connector cable from the left I/O board.

item.Text: thread the gray and black power cable beneath the speaker cable . and lift the battery connector out of the computer .

item.Text_raw: Thread the gray and black power cable beneath the speaker cable, and lift the battery connector out of the computer.

item.Text: do not yank the upper case off quickly . the case is attached to the logic board via a ribbon cable .

lift up at the rear of the case and work your fingers along the sides . freeing the case as you go . once you have freed the sides . you may need to rock the case up and down to free the front of the upper case . this stage can be quite tricky . over the dvd reader are 4 tabs set back which pull out vertically .

note that the two small tongues on the left hand front of the upper case may bend while you remove the upper case . when re-installing . you may need to bend them back to fit in the grooves in the lower case .

item.Text_raw: Do not yank the upper case off quickly. The case is attached to the logic board via a ribbon cable. Lift up at the rear of the case and work your fingers along the sides, freeing the case as you go. Once you have freed the sides, you may need to rock the case up and down to free the front of the upper case. This stage can be quite tricky. Over the DVD reader are 4 tabs set back which pull out vertically. Note that the two small tongues on the left hand front of the upper case may bend while you remove the upper case. When re-installing, you may need to bend them back to fit in the grooves in the lower case.

remove the upper case .

the 4.8 mm screw may be a t6 torx

item.Title: MacBook Pro 15" Core Duo Model A1150 Battery Connector Replacement
item.Category: MacBook Pro 15" Core Duo Model A1150

item.Text: use your fingers to push both battery release tabs away from the battery . and lift the battery out of the computer .

item.Text_raw: Use your fingers to push both battery release tabs away from the battery, and lift the battery out of the computer.

item.Text: remove the three identical phillips screws from the memory door .
make sure to record which sets of screws came from where . this will help when re-assembling .

item.Text_raw: Remove the three identical Phillips screws from the memory door. Make sure to record which sets of screws came from where. This will help when re-assembling.

item.Text: lift the memory door up enough to get a grip on it . and slide it toward you . pulling it away from the casing .

item.Text_raw: Lift the memory door up enough to get a grip on it, and slide it toward you, pulling it away from the casing.

item.Text: remove the two phillips screws in the battery compartment near the latch .

item.Text_raw: Remove the two Phillips screws in the battery compartment near the latch.

item.Text: remove the following 6 screws .
two 10 mm t6 torx screws on either side of the ram slot .
four 14.5 mm phillips screws along the hinge .

item.Text_raw: Remove the following 6 screws: Two 10 mm T6 Torx screws on either side of the RAM slot. Four 14.5 mm Phillips screws along the hinge.

item.Text: remove the four phillips screws on the port side of the computer .

item.Text_raw: Remove the four Phillips screws on the port side of the computer.

item.Text: rotate the computer 90 degrees and remove the two phillips screws from the rear of the computer .

item.Text_raw: Rotate the computer 90 degrees and remove the two Phillips screws from the rear of the computer.

item.Text: rotate the computer 90 degrees again and remove the four phillips screws from the side of the computer .

item.Text_raw: Rotate the computer 90 degrees again and remove the four Phillips screws from the side of the computer.

item.Text: do not yank the upper case off quickly . the case is attached to the logic board via a ribbon cable .

lift up at the rear of the case and work your fingers along the sides . freeing the case as you go . once you have freed the sides . you may need to rock the case up and down to free the front of the upper case . this stage can be quite tricky . over the dvd reader are 4 tabs set back which pull out vertically .

note that the two small tongues on the left hand front of the upper case may bend while you remove the upper case . when re-installing . you may need to bend them back to fit in the grooves in the lower case .

item.Text_raw: Do not yank the upper case off quickly. The case is attached to the logic board via a ribbon cable. Lift up at the rear of the case and work your fingers along the sides, freeing the case as you go. Once you have freed the sides, you may need to rock the case up and down to free the front of the upper case. This stage can be quite tricky. Over the DVD reader are 4 tabs set back which pull out vertically. Note that the two small tongues on the left hand front of the upper case may bend while you remove the upper case. When re-installing, you may need to bend them back to fit in the grooves in the lower case.

item.Text: disconnect the trackpad and keyboard ribbon cable from the logic board . removing tape as necessary .
remove the upper case .

item.Text_raw: Disconnect the trackpad and keyboard ribbon cable from the logic board, removing tape as necessary. Remove the upper case.

item.Text: disconnect the orange superdrive ribbon cable from the logic board . removing tape as necessary .

item.Text_raw: Disconnect the orange SuperDrive ribbon cable from the logic board, removing tape as necessary.

item.Text: remove the following 3 screws .
two 3.3 mm silver phillips screws on either side of the superdrive .
one 4.8 mm black phillips screw at the top right corner of the drive .
the 4.8 mm screw may be a t6 torx

item.Text_raw: Remove the following 3 screws: Two 3.3 mm silver Phillips screws on either side of the SuperDrive. One 4.8 mm black Phillips screw at the top right corner of the drive. The 4.8mm screw may be a T6 Torx

item.Text: lift the optical drive up and out of the computer .

item.Text_raw: Lift the optical drive up and out of the computer.

item.Text: disconnect the hard drive and expresscard connectors from the left side of the logic board .

item.Text_raw: Disconnect the hard drive and ExpressCard connectors from the left side of the logic board.

item.Text: disconnect the eight indicated connectors from the logic board . removing tape as necessary .

item.Text_raw: Disconnect the eight indicated connectors from the logic board, removing tape as necessary.

item.Text: use a spudger to flip up the brown plastic flap securing the left ambient light sensor cable to the logic board .
slide the left ambient light sensor cable to the left and out of its connector .

item.Text_raw: Use a spudger to flip up the brown plastic flap securing the left ambient light sensor cable to the logic board. Slide the left ambient light sensor cable to the left and out of its connector.

item.Text: remove the silver t6 torx screw securing the ground loop on the display data cable to the casing .

item.Text_raw: Remove the silver T6 Torx screw securing the ground loop on the display data cable to the casing.

item.Text: remove the single silver t6 torx screw securing the clear plastic shield over the right ambient light sensor .
lift the clear plastic shield off the right ambient light sensor .

item.Text_raw: Remove the single silver T6 Torx screw securing the clear plastic shield over the right ambient light sensor. Lift the clear plastic shield off the right ambient light sensor.

item.Text: peel up the orange kapton tape securing the right thermal sensor cable to the logic board .

item.Text_raw: Peel up the orange Kapton tape securing the right thermal sensor cable to the logic board.

item.name: nine 4.7 mm silver t6 torx screws
one 6.2 mm black t6 torx screw
five 9.4 mm silver t6 torx screws

Step_level_parts.item: five 9.4 mm silver t6 torx screws
nine 4.7 mm silver t6 torx screws
one 6.2 mm black t6 torx screw

item.Text: remove the following 16 screws . moving cables as necessary .
one 4.4 mm black phillips screw to the right of the ram slot .
nine 4.7 mm silver t6 torx screws securing the logic board to the lower case .
one 6.2 mm black t6 torx screw on the right side of the left fan .
five 9.4 mm silver t6 torx screws securing the left and right fans .

item.Text_raw: Remove the following 16 screws, moving cables as necessary: One 4.4 mm black Phillips screw to the right of the RAM slot. Nine 4.7 mm silver T6 Torx screws securing the logic board to the lower case. One 6.2 mm black T6 Torx screw on the right side of the left fan. Five 9.4 mm silver T6 Torx screws securing the left and right fans.

item.Text: move the display data cable to the right . removing tape as necessary .
peel up and remove the orange foil shield near the right speaker .

item.Text_raw: Move the display data cable to the right, removing tape as necessary. Peel up and remove the orange foil shield near the right speaker.

item.Text: rotate the speaker clockwise approximately 30 degrees until it comes free from the logic board .

item.Text_raw: Rotate the speaker clockwise approximately 30 degrees until it comes free from the logic board.

item.Text: peel up the gray and black speaker wires from the top of the logic board . removing tape as necessary .

item.Text_raw: Peel up the gray and black speaker wires from the top of the logic board, removing tape as necessary.

item.Text: peel up the isight and inverter board cables from above the left fan .

hold the logic board down with one hand and use your other hand to lift the left fan up from its housing . there is a piece of black tape securing the fan to the heat sink . carefully peel this tape up from the heat sink as you lift the fan up .
place the fan above the airport card . it is not necessary to entirely remove the fan from the computer .

item.Text_raw: Peel up the iSight and inverter board cables from above the left fan. Hold the logic board down with one hand and use your other hand to lift the left fan up from its housing. There is a piece of black tape securing the fan to the heat sink. Carefully peel this tape up from the heat sink as you lift the fan up. Place the fan above the Airport card. It is not necessary to entirely remove the fan from the computer.

item.Text: it may be helpful to hold the heat sink in place while removing the right fan .
lift the right fan up while carefully peeling up the tape which secures the fan to the heat sink .
remove the right fan from the computer .

item.Text_raw: It may be helpful to hold the heat sink in place while removing the right fan. Lift the right fan up while carefully peeling up the tape which secures the fan to the heat sink. Remove the right fan from the computer.

item.Text: lift up the left side of the logic board and disconnect the multi-colored power cable from the bottom of the board .

item.Text_raw: Lift up the left side of the logic board and disconnect the multi-colored power cable from the bottom of the board.

item.Text: the logic board is still attached to the computer by one more cable . so don't lift the logic board too far out of the computer yet .
grasp the logic board at the left side and at the thin section . and rotate the logic board out of the lower case .

to properly reassemble your macbook pro . you'll have to clean off and replace the old thermal compound from the chips on the back of the logic board . use our guide to prepare the processor and heat sink surfaces .

item.Text_raw: The logic board is still attached to the computer by one more cable, so don't lift the logic board too far out of the computer yet. Grasp the logic board at the left side and at the thin section, and rotate the logic board out of the lower case. To properly reassemble your MacBook Pro, you'll have to clean off and replace the old thermal compound from the chips on the back of the logic board. Use our [guide|744|Applying Thermal Paste Guide] to prepare the processor and heat sink surfaces.

item.Text: disconnect the right thermal sensor cable from the bottom of the logic board near the dvi port .

item.Text_raw: Disconnect the right thermal sensor cable from the bottom of the logic board near the DVI port.

item.Text: remove the two silver t6 torx screws securing the battery connector to the lower case .

item.Text_raw: Remove the two silver T6 Torx screws securing the battery connector to the lower case.

item.Text: disconnect the large multi-colored battery connector cable from the left i/o board .

item.Text_raw: Disconnect the large multi-colored battery connector cable from the left I/O board.

item.Text: peel up the orange tape securing the battery connector to the lower case . and lift the battery connector out of the computer .

item.Text_raw: Peel up the orange tape securing the battery connector to the lower case, and lift the battery connector out of the computer.

item.Title: MacBook Pro 15" Core 2 Duo Models A1226 and A1260 Battery Connector Replacement
item.Category: MacBook Pro 15" Core 2 Duo Models A1226 and A1260

item.Text: use your fingers to push both battery release tabs away from the battery . and lift the battery out of the computer .

item.Text_raw: Use your fingers to push both battery release tabs away from the battery, and lift the battery out of the computer.

item.Text: remove the three identical 2 mm 000 phillips screws from the memory door .
lift the memory door up enough to grip it and slide it toward you . pulling it away from the casing .

item.Text_raw: Remove the three identical 2mm PH000 Phillips screws from the memory door. Lift the memory door up enough to grip it and slide it toward you, pulling it away from the casing.

item.Text: remove the two 2.8 mm phillips screws in the battery compartment near the latch .

item.Text_raw: Remove the two 2.8 mm Phillips screws in the battery compartment near the latch.

item.Text: remove the following 6 screws .
two 10 mm t6 torx screws on either side of the ram slot .
four 14.5 mm phillips screws along the hinge .

item.Text_raw: Remove the following 6 screws: Two 10 mm T6 Torx screws on either side of the RAM slot. Four 14.5 mm Phillips screws along the hinge.

item.Text: remove the four 3.2 mm 00 phillips screws on the port side of the computer .

item.Text_raw: Remove the four 3.2 mm PH00 Phillips screws on the port side of the computer.

item.Text: rotate the computer 90 degrees and remove the two 3.2 mm phillips screws from the rear of the computer .

item.Text_raw: Rotate the computer 90 degrees and remove the two 3.2 mm Phillips screws from the rear of the computer.

item.Text: rotate the computer 90 degrees again and remove the four 3.2 mm phillips screws from the side of the computer .

item.Text_raw: Rotate the computer 90 degrees again and remove the four 3.2 mm Phillips screws from the side of the computer.

item.Text: do not yank the upper case off quickly . the case is attached to the logic board via a ribbon cable .

lift up at the rear of the case and work your fingers along the sides . freeing the case as you go . once you have freed the sides . you may need to rock the case up and down to free the front of the upper case .

there are four plastic clips above the dvd slot . and another above and to the left of the ir sensor . these clips can be very difficult to disengage without prying . they can also be difficult to re-engage during reassembly .
'''reassembly tip . ''' press down firmly on the tip of the top case above the location of each clip until you hear a ''snap'' to reseat them in their slots .

'''reassembly tip . ''' the two center dvd clips will rarely snap back into place properly without help . and downward pressure will instead simply deform the frame around the dvd slot . support the frame by inserting a plastic spudger into the dvd slot directly under the clip location until it is snug . then press down until you hear the ''snap'' .

item.Text_raw: Do not yank the upper case off quickly. The case is attached to the logic board via a ribbon cable. Lift up at the rear of the case and work your fingers along the sides, freeing the case as you go. Once you have freed the sides, you may need to rock the case up and down to free the front of the upper case. There are four plastic clips above the DVD slot, and another above and to the left of the IR sensor. These clips can be very difficult to disengage without prying. They can also be difficult to re-engage during reassembly. '''Reassembly Tip:''' Press down firmly on the tip of the top case above the location of each clip until you hear a ''snap'' to reseat them in their slots. '''Reassembly Tip:''' The two center DVD clips will rarely snap back into place properly without help, and downward pressure will instead simply deform the frame around the DVD slot. Support the frame by inserting a plastic spudger into the DVD slot directly under the clip location until it is snug, then press down until you hear the ''snap''.

item.Text: disconnect the trackpad and keyboard ribbon cable from the logic board . removing tape as necessary .

note . it is possible to replace the hard drive without disconnecting the keyboard from the chassis . but it will need to be held upright to keep it out of the way . while still allowing you both hands to work on the drive removal .

be careful when removing the keyboard-trackpad ribbon cable to ensure that the rear of the upper case is disengaged from the area near the hinge . it is easy to accidentally bend the screw receivers on either side of the keyboard .
remove the upper case .

item.Text_raw: Disconnect the trackpad and keyboard ribbon cable from the logic board, removing tape as necessary. Note: It is possible to replace the hard drive without disconnecting the keyboard from the chassis, but it will need to be held upright to keep it out of the way, while still allowing you both hands to work on the drive removal. Be careful when removing the keyboard-trackpad ribbon cable to ensure that the rear of the upper case is disengaged from the area near the hinge. It is easy to accidentally bend the screw receivers on either side of the keyboard. Remove the upper case.

item.Text: use the flat end of a spudger to disconnect the orange superdrive ribbon cable from the logic board . removing tape as necessary .

item.Text_raw: Use the flat end of a spudger to disconnect the orange SuperDrive ribbon cable from the logic board, removing tape as necessary.

item.name: One 4.7 mm silver T6 Torx screw

item.Text: remove the following 4 screws .
two 3.3 mm silver phillips screws on either side of the superdrive .
one 4.7 mm silver t6 torx screw from the top left corner of the drive .
one 6.2 mm black phillips screw at the top right corner of the drive .
lift the optical drive up and out of the computer .

item.Text_raw: Remove the following 4 screws: Two 3.3 mm silver Phillips screws on either side of the SuperDrive. One 4.7 mm silver T6 Torx screw from the top left corner of the drive. One 6.2 mm black Phillips screw at the top right corner of the drive. Lift the optical drive up and out of the computer.

item.Text: disconnect the hard drive and expresscard connectors from the left side of the logic board .

item.Text_raw: Disconnect the hard drive and ExpressCard connectors from the left side of the logic board.

item.Text: disconnect the isight and display data cables from the logic board by sliding the cables out of their connectors . removing tape as necessary .

item.Text_raw: Disconnect the iSight and display data cables from the logic board by sliding the cables out of their connectors, removing tape as necessary.

item.Text: disconnect the eight indicated connectors by placing a spudger beneath each one and lifting up .
use care when disconnecting some of the smaller connectors . a forceful prod with the spudger may accidentally break them off the logic board .

item.Text_raw: Disconnect the eight indicated connectors by placing a spudger beneath each one and lifting up. Use care when disconnecting some of the smaller connectors. A forceful prod with the spudger may accidentally break them off the logic board.

item.Text: remove the foam bumper from the top of the right hinge of the display .

item.Text_raw: Remove the foam bumper from the top of the right hinge of the display.

item.Text: remove the silver 9.5 mm t6 torx screw securing the ground loop in the display data cable to the casing .

item.Text_raw: Remove the silver 9.5 mm T6 Torx screw securing the ground loop in the display data cable to the casing.

item.name: single black 6 mm T6 Torx screw

item.Text: remove the single black 6 mm t6 torx screw securing the upper portion of the logic board to the upper case .

item.Text_raw: Remove the single black 6 mm T6 Torx screw securing the upper portion of the logic board to the upper case.

item.Text: peel up the orange kapton tape securing the right thermal sensor cable to the logic board .

item.Text_raw: Peel up the orange Kapton tape securing the right thermal sensor cable to the logic board.

item.name: Eight 4.7 mm silver T6 Torx screws
One 6.2 mm black T6 Torx screw
Five 9.4 mm silver T6 Torx screws

Step_level_parts.item: five 9.4 mm silver t6 torx screws
eight 4.7 mm silver t6 torx screws
one 6.2 mm black t6 torx screw

item.Text: remove the following 15 screws .
one 4.4 mm black phillips screw to the right of the ram slot .
eight 4.7 mm silver t6 torx screws securing the logic board to the lower case .

if you leave the five uppermost orange screws in place . the heatsink/pipes come out effortlessly . still mounted onto the main board . that way its thermal connection is retained . and you won't need to reapply thermal paste as instructed two steps below .
one 6.2 mm black t6 torx screw on the right side of the left fan .
five 9.4 mm silver t6 torx screws securing the left and right fans .

item.Text_raw: Remove the following 15 screws: One 4.4 mm black Phillips screw to the right of the ram slot. Eight 4.7 mm silver T6 Torx screws securing the logic board to the lower case. If you leave the five uppermost orange screws in place, the heatsink/pipes come out effortlessly, still mounted onto the main board. That way its thermal connection is retained, and you won't need to reapply thermal paste as instructed two steps below. One 6.2 mm black T6 Torx screw on the right side of the left fan. Five 9.4 mm silver T6 Torx screws securing the left and right fans.

item.Text: hold the logic board down with one hand and use your other hand to lift the left fan up from its housing . there is a piece of black tape securing the left fan to the heat sink . carefully peel this tape up from the heat sink as you lift the left fan up .
place the left fan above the airport card . it is not necessary to remove the fan from the computer entirely .
lift the right fan up and carefully peel up the tape securing the fan to the heat sink as you go .
remove the right fan from the computer .

item.Text_raw: Hold the logic board down with one hand and use your other hand to lift the left fan up from its housing. There is a piece of black tape securing the left fan to the heat sink. Carefully peel this tape up from the heat sink as you lift the left fan up. Place the left fan above the Airport card. It is not necessary to remove the fan from the computer entirely. Lift the right fan up and carefully peel up the tape securing the fan to the heat sink as you go. Remove the right fan from the computer.

item.Text: lift up the left side of the logic board and disconnect the gray and black power cable from the bottom of the board .
pull the power cable connector parallel to the face of the logic board .
grasp the logic board at the left side and at the thin section . and rotate the logic board out of the lower case .

if you detached the heatsink from the motherboard two steps above . you'll have to clean off and replace the old thermal compound from the chips on the back of the logic board . use our guide to prepare the processor and heat sink surfaces .

item.Text_raw: Lift up the left side of the logic board and disconnect the gray and black power cable from the bottom of the board. Pull the power cable connector parallel to the face of the logic board. Grasp the logic board at the left side and at the thin section, and rotate the logic board out of the lower case. If you detached the heatsink from the motherboard two steps above, you'll have to clean off and replace the old thermal compound from the chips on the back of the logic board. Use our [guide|744|Applying Thermal Paste Guide] to prepare the processor and heat sink surfaces.

item.Text: remove the two silver t6 torx screws securing the battery connector to the lower case .

item.Text_raw: Remove the two silver T6 Torx screws securing the battery connector to the lower case.

item.Text: disconnect the large gray and black battery connector cable from the left i/o board .

item.Text_raw: Disconnect the large gray and black battery connector cable from the left I/O board.

item.Text: thread the gray and black power cable beneath the speaker cable . and lift the battery connector out of the computer .

item.Text_raw: Thread the gray and black power cable beneath the speaker cable, and lift the battery connector out of the computer.

item.Title: MacBook Pro 15" Unibody Late 2008 and Early 2009 Battery Connector Replacement
item.Category: MacBook Pro 15" Unibody Late 2008 and Early 2009

item.Text: with the case closed . place the unibody top-side down on a flat surface .
depress the grooved side of the access door release latch enough to grab the free end . lift the release latch until it is vertical .

item.Text_raw: With the case closed, place the Unibody top-side down on a flat surface. Depress the grooved side of the access door release latch enough to grab the free end. Lift the release latch until it is vertical.

item.Text: the access door should now be raised enough to lift it up and out of the unibody .

item.Text_raw: The access door should now be raised enough to lift it up and out of the Unibody.

item.Text: be sure the access door release latch is vertical before proceeding .
grab the translucent plastic tab and pull the battery up and out of the unibody .
if the latch is depressed it will lock the battery in place .

item.Text_raw: Be sure the access door release latch is vertical before proceeding. Grab the translucent plastic tab and pull the battery up and out of the Unibody. If the latch is depressed it will lock the battery in place.

item.Text: remove the following eight screws securing the lower case to the chassis .
one 5.4 mm phillips screw .
three 14 mm phillips screws .
four 3.5 mm phillips screws .

item.Text_raw: Remove the following eight screws securing the lower case to the chassis: One 5.4 mm Phillips screw. Three 14 mm Phillips screws. Four 3.5 mm Phillips screws.

item.Text: using both hands . lift and remove the lower case off the upper case .

item.Text_raw: Using both hands, lift and remove the lower case off the upper case.

item.Text: remove the following 5 screws securing the mid wall to the upper case .
three 10.5 mm phillips screws .
two 3.7 mm phillips screws .

item.Text_raw: Remove the following 5 screws securing the mid wall to the upper case: Three 10.5 mm Phillips screws. Two 3.7 mm Phillips screws.

item.Text: lift the mid wall out of the upper case .

item.Text_raw: Lift the mid wall out of the upper case.

item.Text: remove the following six screws securing both the right fan and the left fan to the logic board .
four 3.5 mm phillips screws .
two 3.2 mm phillips screws .

item.Text_raw: Remove the following six screws securing both the right fan and the left fan to the logic board: Four 3.5 mm Phillips screws. Two 3.2 mm Phillips screws.

item.Text: use the tip of a spudger to lift the right fan connector straight up from its socket on the logic board .
be sure to only pry up on the connector itself '''not on the socket''' or you may damage the machine .
it is useful to twist the spudger axially from beneath the fan cable wires to release the connector .
remove the right fan from the case .

item.Text_raw: Use the tip of a spudger to lift the right fan connector straight up from its socket on the logic board. Be sure to only pry up on the connector itself '''not on the socket''' or you may damage the machine. It is useful to twist the spudger axially from beneath the fan cable wires to release the connector. Remove the right fan from the case.

item.Text: use the tip of a spudger to lift the left fan connector straight up from its socket on the logic board .
be sure to only pry up on the connector itself '''not on the socket''' or you may damage the machine .
it is useful to twist the spudger axially from beneath the fan cable wires to release the connector .
remove the left fan from the case .

item.Text_raw: Use the tip of a spudger to lift the left fan connector straight up from its socket on the logic board. Be sure to only pry up on the connector itself '''not on the socket''' or you may damage the machine. It is useful to twist the spudger axially from beneath the fan cable wires to release the connector. Remove the left fan from the case.

item.Text: remove any adhesive from the camera cable connector .
disconnect the camera cable by pulling the male end out of its socket . parallel to the logic board . '''do not''' lift it upwards .

item.Text_raw: Remove any adhesive from the camera cable connector. Disconnect the camera cable by pulling the male end out of its socket, parallel to the logic board, '''do not''' lift it upwards.

item.Text: use a spudger to carefully pry the optical drive connector straight up off its socket on the logic board .

item.Text_raw: Use a spudger to carefully pry the optical drive connector straight up off its socket on the logic board.

item.Text: if necessary . peel off the foam bumper covering the subwoofer connector .
using the flat end of a spudger . pry the subwoofer connector straight up off its socket on the logic board .
be very careful . this connection is delicate . the socket can be easily broken off the logic board .

item.Text_raw: If necessary, peel off the foam bumper covering the subwoofer connector. Using the flat end of a spudger, pry the subwoofer connector straight up off its socket on the logic board. Be very careful. This connection is delicate, the socket can be easily broken off the logic board.

item.Text: use the flat end of a spudger to pry the silver-colored hard drive cable connector straight up out of its socket on the logic board .

item.Text_raw: Use the flat end of a spudger to pry the silver-colored hard drive cable connector straight up out of its socket on the logic board.

item.Text: use a spudger to pry the trackpad connector straight up out of its socket on the logic board .

item.Text_raw: Use a spudger to pry the trackpad connector straight up out of its socket on the logic board.

item.Text: using the tip of a spudger . flip up the ir/sleep led ribbon cable retaining flap .
pull the ir/sleep led ribbon cable straight out of its socket .

item.Text_raw: Using the tip of a spudger, flip up the IR/sleep LED ribbon cable retaining flap. Pull the IR/sleep LED ribbon cable straight out of its socket.

item.Text: use a spudger to pry the battery indicator light connector straight up out of its socket on the logic board .
pry up under the cable wires to avoid pulling the socket itself off of the logic board .

item.Text_raw: Use a spudger to pry the battery indicator light connector straight up out of its socket on the logic board. Pry up under the cable wires to avoid pulling the socket itself off of the logic board.

item.Text: using the tip of a spudger . flip up the keyboard ribbon cable retaining flap .
pull the keyboard ribbon cable straight out of its socket .
during reassembly . make sure to fully insert the keyboard ribbon cable back into the zif socket .

item.Text_raw: Using the tip of a spudger, flip up the keyboard ribbon cable retaining flap. Pull the keyboard ribbon cable straight out of its socket. During reassembly, make sure to fully insert the keyboard ribbon cable back into the ZIF socket.

item.Text: using the tip of a spudger . flip up the express card cage ribbon cable retaining flap .
pull the express card cage ribbon cable straight out of its socket .

item.Text_raw: Using the tip of a spudger, flip up the express card cage ribbon cable retaining flap. Pull the express card cage ribbon cable straight out of its socket.

item.Text: using the flat end of a spudger . pry the microphone cable connector straight up out of its socket on the logic board .
pry up under the cable wires to avoid pulling the socket itself off of the logic board .

item.Text_raw: Using the flat end of a spudger, pry the microphone cable connector straight up out of its socket on the logic board. Pry up under the cable wires to avoid pulling the socket itself off of the logic board.

item.Text: grab the plastic pull tab secured to the display data cable lock and rotate it toward the dc-in side of the computer .
pull the display data cable connector straight away from its socket .

when disconnecting the display data cable . do not pull on the black tab secured to the cable lock . we recommend wiggling the cable while applying tension to slowly walk the connector out of its socket .
make sure the display data cable is placed correctly in its socket during reassembly . failure to do so will result in a partially visible display or no display image at all .

item.Text_raw: Grab the plastic pull tab secured to the display data cable lock and rotate it toward the DC-in side of the computer. Pull the display data cable connector straight away from its socket. When disconnecting the display data cable, do not pull on the black tab secured to the cable lock. We recommend wiggling the cable while applying tension to slowly "walk" the connector out of its socket. Make sure the display data cable is placed correctly in its socket during reassembly. Failure to do so will result in a partially visible display or no display image at all.

item.Text: locate the keyboard backlight ribbon cable ( near the left fan space ) .
using the tip of a spudger . flip up the keyboard backlight ribbon cable retaining flap .
pull the keyboard backlight ribbon cable straight out of its socket .

item.Text_raw: Locate the keyboard backlight ribbon cable (near the left fan space). Using the tip of a spudger, flip up the keyboard backlight ribbon cable retaining flap. Pull the keyboard backlight ribbon cable straight out of its socket.

item.Text: remove seven 3.2 mm phillips screws securing the logic board to the upper case .
do not remove the logic board yet ! there are connectors attached to the underside of the logic board that must first be disconnected .

item.Text_raw: Remove seven 3.2 mm Phillips screws securing the logic board to the upper case. Do not remove the logic board yet! There are connectors attached to the underside of the logic board that must first be disconnected.

item.Text: remove two 7 mm phillips screws securing the dc-in board to the upper case .
note . this step is not completely necessary . but it will make it easier to disconnect the cable that is connected to the dc-in board .

item.Text_raw: Remove two 7 mm Phillips screws securing the DC-in board to the upper case. Note: This step is not completely necessary, but it will make it easier to disconnect the cable that is connected to the DC-in board.

item.Text: remove two 3.5 mm phillips screws securing the bottom case clip to the upper case .
lift the bottom case clip out of the upper case .
some macbook pro unibodies do not have a bottom case clip and do not require this step .

item.Text_raw: Remove two 3.5 mm Phillips screws securing the bottom case clip to the upper case. Lift the bottom case clip out of the upper case. Some MacBook Pro Unibodies do not have a bottom case clip and do not require this step.

item.Text: carefully lift the logic board assembly from the left side and work it out of the upper case . minding the port side that may get caught during removal .
'''do not''' entirely remove the logic board yet !
ensure that the logic board is free from all connections to the upper case ( except the battery connector ) before proceeding .
during reassembly . ensure all connectors and cables are not placed underneath the logic board . some of the ribbon cables are very thin and fragile .

item.Text_raw: Carefully lift the logic board assembly from the left side and work it out of the upper case, minding the port side that may get caught during removal. '''Do not''' entirely remove the logic board yet! Ensure that the logic board is free from all connections to the upper case (except the battery connector) before proceeding. During reassembly, ensure all connectors and cables are not placed underneath the logic board. Some of the ribbon cables are very thin and fragile.

item.Text: lift the logic board enough to grab the battery connector and pull it straight away from its socket on the logic board .
lift the logic board assembly out of the upper case .

item.Text_raw: Lift the logic board enough to grab the battery connector and pull it straight away from its socket on the logic board. Lift the logic board assembly out of the upper case.

item.Text: remove three 2 mm phillips screws securing the battery connector cover to the upper case .

item.Text_raw: Remove three 2 mm Phillips screws securing the battery connector cover to the upper case.

item.Text: the battery connector cover is held onto the upper case by a strong adhesive . use a spudger to loosen the adhesive around the edges of the battery connector .
lift the battery connector cover out of the upper case .

item.Text_raw: The battery connector cover is held onto the upper case by a strong adhesive. Use a spudger to loosen the adhesive around the edges of the battery connector. Lift the battery connector cover out of the upper case.

item.Text: peel the battery connector cable off the adhesive securing it to the upper case .
de-route the battery connector cable through the gap in the upper case and remove it from the computer .

item.Text_raw: Peel the battery connector cable off the adhesive securing it to the upper case. De-route the battery connector cable through the gap in the upper case and remove it from the computer.

item.Title: MacBook Pro 13" Retina Display Late 2012 Battery Replacement

item.Name: macbook pro and air 5-point pentalobe screwdriver

Tools.item: p5 pentalobe screwdriver retina macbook pro and air

item.Text: remove the following ten screws securing the lower case to the upper case .
two 2.3 mm p5 pentalobe screws
eight 3.0 mm p5 pentalobe screws
throughout this repair . track of each screw and make sure it goes back exactly where it came from to avoid damaging your device .

item.Text_raw: Remove the following ten screws securing the lower case to the upper case: Two 2.3 mm P5 Pentalobe screws Eight 3.0 mm P5 Pentalobe screws Throughout this repair, [https://www.ifixit.com/Store/Tools/Magnetic-Project-Mat/IF145-167-4|keep track of each screw|new_window=true] and make sure it goes back exactly where it came from to avoid damaging your device.

item.Text: wedge your fingers between the upper case and the lower case .
gently pull the lower case away from the upper case .
remove the lower case and set it aside .

item.Text_raw: Wedge your fingers between the upper case and the lower case. Gently pull the lower case away from the upper case. Remove the lower case and set it aside.

item.Text: the lower case is connected to the upper case at the center . with two plastic clips .
during reassembly . gently push down the center of the lower case to reattach the two plastic clips .

item.Text_raw: The lower case is connected to the upper case at the center, with two plastic clips. During reassembly, gently push down the center of the lower case to reattach the two plastic clips.

item.Text: remove the plastic cover adhered to the battery contact board .

item.Text_raw: Remove the plastic cover adhered to the battery contact board.

item.Text: remove the following screws securing the battery connector board to the logic board .
two 2.8 mm t6 torx screws
one 7.0 mm t6 torx shouldered screw

item.Text_raw: Remove the following screws securing the battery connector board to the logic board: Two 2.8 mm T6 Torx screws One 7.0 mm T6 Torx shouldered screw

item.Text: use tweezers to remove the small plastic cover located near the bottom right of the battery connector board .

item.Text_raw: Use tweezers to remove the small plastic cover located near the bottom right of the battery connector board.

item.Text: remove the wide head 6.4 mm t6 torx screw securing the battery connector to the logic board assembly .

item.Text_raw: Remove the wide head 6.4 mm T6 Torx screw securing the battery connector to the logic board assembly.

item.Text: carefully lift the battery connector board up off the logic board .
it is recommended to bend the battery cables just slightly . to keep the board suspended up above the logic board and out of the way .
do not fold the board completely over . or crease the cables . as this may damage the battery .

item.Text_raw: Carefully lift the battery connector board up off the logic board. It is recommended to bend the battery cables just slightly, to keep the board suspended up above the logic board and out of the way. Do not fold the board completely over, or crease the cables, as this may damage the battery.

item.Text: grasp the interposer with tweezers .
an interposer is the name for an interface that links one electrical connection to another . in this repair . it is the board connecting the battery to logic board .
lift the interposer off the logic board and remove it .

removing this board will ensure that the battery remains disconnected throughout your repair . preventing your computer from accidentally powering on . it's also a good idea to take it out so it doesn't fall out unexpectedly .

item.Text_raw: Grasp the Interposer with tweezers. An interposer is the name for an interface that links one electrical connection to another. In this repair, it is the board connecting the battery to logic board. Lift the Interposer off the logic board and remove it. Removing this board will ensure that the battery remains disconnected throughout your repair, preventing your computer from accidentally powering on. It's also a good idea to take it out so it doesn't fall out unexpectedly.

item.Text: use the flat end of a spudger to pry the right side of the i/o board data cable connector up off its socket on the i/o board .
when prying the i/o board data cable connector from its socket . make sure to pry the connector itself and not the socket . prying the socket may cause irreversible damage to the i/o board .

item.Text_raw: Use the flat end of a spudger to pry the right side of the I/O board data cable connector up off its socket on the I/O board. When prying the I/O board data cable connector from its socket, make sure to pry the connector itself and not the socket. Prying the socket may cause irreversible damage to the I/O board.

item.Text: wedge the flat end of a spudger beneath the left side of the i/o board data cable connector .
gently twist the spudger to disconnect the i/o board data cable connector from its socket on the logic board .

item.Text_raw: Wedge the flat end of a spudger beneath the left side of the I/O board data cable connector. Gently twist the spudger to disconnect the I/O board data cable connector from its socket on the logic board.

item.Text: lift and remove the i/o board data cable from the macbook pro .

item.Text_raw: Lift and remove the I/O board data cable from the MacBook Pro.

item.Text: use the flat end of a spudger to pry the ssd cable connector up from its socket on the logic board .
move the ssd cable connector out of the way .

item.Text_raw: Use the flat end of a spudger to pry the SSD cable connector up from its socket on the logic board. Move the SSD cable connector out of the way.

item.Text: wedge the flat end of a spudger beneath the right speaker cable connector .
gently pry the right speaker cable connector up off from its socket on the logic board .
be sure you are prying up on the connector . '''not''' the socket itself .

item.Text_raw: Wedge the flat end of a spudger beneath the right speaker cable connector. Gently pry the right speaker cable connector up off from its socket on the logic board. Be sure you are prying up on the connector, '''not''' the socket itself.

item.Text: remove the following screws securing the right speaker to the upper case .
one 6.8 mm t5 torx screw
two 6.3 mm t5 torx screws
the corner screw may be covered with a foam pad . if so . use your tweezers to peel it up and remove it .

item.Text_raw: Remove the following screws securing the right speaker to the upper case: One 6.8 mm T5 Torx screw Two 6.3 mm T5 Torx screws The corner screw may be covered with a foam pad. If so, use your tweezers to peel it up and remove it.

item.Text: lift and remove the right speaker out of the upper case .
if necessary . de-route the right speaker cable from its channel in the upper case .

item.Text_raw: Lift and remove the right speaker out of the upper case. If necessary, de-route the right speaker cable from its channel in the upper case.

item.Text: use the flat end of a spudger to pry the headphone jack cable connector straight up off its socket on the logic board .
gently bend the headphone jack cable to 90 up from the logic board .
bending the headphone jack cable will allow you to disconnect the left speaker cable connector without having the headphone jack cable in the way .

item.Text_raw: Use the flat end of a spudger to pry the headphone jack cable connector straight up off its socket on the logic board. Gently bend the headphone jack cable to 90° up from the logic board. Bending the headphone jack cable will allow you to disconnect the left speaker cable connector without having the headphone jack cable in the way.

item.Text: wedge the tip of a spudger beneath the left speaker cable connector .
gently pry the left speaker cable connector up off from its socket on the logic board .
be sure you are prying up on the connector . '''not''' the socket itself .

item.Text_raw: Wedge the tip of a spudger beneath the left speaker cable connector. Gently pry the left speaker cable connector up off from its socket on the logic board. Be sure you are prying up on the connector, '''not''' the socket itself.

item.Text: remove the following screws securing the left speaker to the upper case .
one 6.8 mm t5 torx screw ( top right )
two 6.3 mm t5 torx screws
the corner screw may be covered with a foam pad . if so . use your tweezers to peel it up and remove it .

item.Text_raw: Remove the following screws securing the left speaker to the upper case: One 6.8 mm T5 Torx screw (top right) Two 6.3 mm T5 Torx screws The corner screw may be covered with a foam pad. If so, use your tweezers to peel it up and remove it.

item.Text: lift and remove the left speaker out of the upper case .

item.Text_raw: Lift and remove the left speaker out of the upper case.

item.Text: use your thumb or finger to bend the plastic spring bar on the ssd tray . freeing the two clips at the front side of the device .
while holding the spring bar depressed . tilt the ssd assembly up out of its cavity .

item.Text_raw: Use your thumb or finger to bend the plastic spring bar on the SSD tray, freeing the two clips at the front side of the device. While holding the spring bar depressed, tilt the SSD assembly up out of its cavity.

item.Text: remove the ssd assembly from the upper case .

item.Text_raw: Remove the SSD assembly from the upper case.

item.Text: remove three 2.2 mm t5 torx screws from each side of the battery ( six screws total ) .

item.Text_raw: Remove three 2.2 mm T5 Torx screws from each side of the battery (six screws total).

item.Text: the liquid adhesive remover provided in your kit can affect the antireflective coating on your macbook pro's display .
to protect your display . place a sheet of aluminum foil between the display and keyboard and leave it there while you work .

item.Text_raw: The liquid adhesive remover provided in your kit can affect the antireflective coating on your MacBook Pro's display. To protect your display, place a sheet of aluminum foil between the display and keyboard and leave it there while you work.

item.Text: now that your macbook pro is fully prepped . it's time to prep yourself .
ifixit adhesive remover contains acetone . a mild skin and eye irritant .
wear eye protection when handling and applying the adhesive remover . ( eye protection is included in your kit . )
'''do not''' wear contact lenses without eye protection .
protective gloves are also included in your kit . if you are concerned about skin irritation . put your gloves on now .

item.Text_raw: Now that your MacBook Pro is fully prepped, it's time to prep yourself. iFixit adhesive remover contains acetone, a mild skin and eye irritant. Wear eye protection when handling and applying the adhesive remover. (Eye protection is included in your kit.) '''Do not''' wear contact lenses without eye protection. Protective gloves are also included in your kit. If you are concerned about skin irritation, put your gloves on now.

item.Text: pull off the black rubber stopper from your bottle of adhesive remover .
twist to loosen or remove the bottle cap before you cut the applicator tip .
this unseals the bottle and allows the pressure to equalize before you cut the applicator tip . '''if you skip this step . the adhesive remover may spray out unexpectedly when the tip is cut . '''
use scissors to cut off the sealed tip of the applicator .
cutting close to the narrow tip will give you better control so you can apply the adhesive remover in small amounts .
twist and close the bottle cap securely before you proceed further .

item.Text_raw: Pull off the black rubber stopper from your bottle of adhesive remover. Twist to loosen or remove the bottle cap before you cut the applicator tip. This unseals the bottle and allows the pressure to equalize before you cut the applicator tip. '''If you skip this step, the adhesive remover may spray out unexpectedly when the tip is cut.''' Use scissors to cut off the sealed tip of the applicator. Cutting close to the narrow tip will give you better control so you can apply the adhesive remover in small amounts. Twist and close the bottle cap securely before you proceed further.

item.Text: apply a few drops of adhesive remover evenly under the edge of the leftmost battery cell .
you don't need to use very much . the small bottle contains more than twice the amount of solvent needed to remove all the battery cells .
wait 2-3 minutes for the liquid adhesive remover to penetrate underneath the battery cell before you proceed to the next step .

item.Text_raw: Apply a few drops of adhesive remover evenly under the edge of the leftmost battery cell. You don't need to use very much. The small bottle contains more than twice the amount of solvent needed to remove all the battery cells. Wait 2-3 minutes for the liquid adhesive remover to penetrate underneath the battery cell before you proceed to the next step.

item.Text: insert the flat edge of a spudger or plastic card underneath the leftmost battery cell .
run your tool along the bottom perimeter of the battery cell and lift to begin separating the adhesive .

item.Text_raw: Insert the flat edge of a spudger or plastic card underneath the leftmost battery cell. Run your tool along the bottom perimeter of the battery cell and lift to begin separating the adhesive.

item.Text: insert the spudger along the left-hand side of the leftmost battery cell .
run the spudger up along the left side of the leftmost battery cell .
slightly pry the leftmost battery cell to release it from the adhesive .

item.Text_raw: Insert the spudger along the left-hand side of the leftmost battery cell. Run the spudger up along the left side of the leftmost battery cell. Slightly pry the leftmost battery cell to release it from the adhesive.

item.Text: repeat the above steps to separate the adjacent battery cell from its adhesive .
apply a few drops of liquid adhesive remover under the battery cell .
wait 2-3 minutes for the adhesive remover to penetrate and soften the adhesive .
carefully wedge a spudger or plastic card inwards . being careful to not damage the battery . and separate the battery cell from the adhesive securing it to your macbook pro .

item.Text_raw: Repeat the above steps to separate the adjacent battery cell from its adhesive: Apply a few drops of liquid adhesive remover under the battery cell. Wait 2-3 minutes for the adhesive remover to penetrate and soften the adhesive. Carefully wedge a spudger or plastic card inwards, being careful to not damage the battery, and separate the battery cell from the adhesive securing it to your MacBook Pro.

item.Text: insert the flat end of a spudger underneath the larger leftmost battery cell .
carefully wedge the spudger inwards . being careful to not damage the battery cells .
pry the larger leftmost battery cell up off the upper case .

item.Text_raw: Insert the flat end of a spudger underneath the larger leftmost battery cell. Carefully wedge the spudger inwards, being careful to not damage the battery cells. Pry the larger leftmost battery cell up off the upper case.

item.Text: grasp the battery cells and gently move ( but do not remove ) them from their recess in the upper case .
leave the battery cells resting on top of the upper case as shown in the third picture .

item.Text_raw: Grasp the battery cells and gently move (but do not remove) them from their recess in the upper case. Leave the battery cells resting on top of the upper case as shown in the third picture.

item.Text: switch sides and repeat the above procedure for the two battery cells on the right-hand side of the macbook pro .
remember to add a small amount of liquid adhesive remover under each battery cell . and wait 2-3 minutes for it to penetrate before prying up the cell .
be careful not to puncture or otherwise damage the battery cells .

item.Text_raw: Switch sides and repeat the above procedure for the two battery cells on the right-hand side of the MacBook Pro. Remember to add a small amount of liquid adhesive remover under each battery cell, and wait 2-3 minutes for it to penetrate before prying up the cell. Be careful not to puncture or otherwise damage the battery cells.

item.Text: lift the battery as a whole up out of the upper case . and remove the battery .
before installing a new battery . remove all the old adhesive from the macbook pro's case .
with a little luck . you can slowly pull out each strip of adhesive with your fingers .

otherwise . soak each section of adhesive with a bit of adhesive remover for 2-3 minutes . and then scrape it out with an opening pick or one of the other tools in your kit . this can take quite a bit of work . so be patient .
mop up any remaining adhesive remover and give your macbook pro a few minutes to air dry .

the replacement battery included in your ifixit kit comes with adhesive pre-installed . test the battery's fit and alignment carefully before peeling off the film covering the adhesive . and then press each cell firmly into place . if any additional films/liners are present that weren't on your original battery . remove them now .

calibrate your new battery before using it . allow it to drain overnight . then charge it to 100 and drain it again until your macbook pro shuts down automatically . charge it again and use it normally .
if you notice any unusual behavior or problems after installing your new battery . you may need to your macbook pro's smc .

item.Text_raw: Lift the battery as a whole up out of the upper case, and remove the battery. Before installing a new battery, remove all the old adhesive from the MacBook Pro's case. With a little luck, you can slowly pull out each strip of adhesive with your fingers. Otherwise, soak each section of adhesive with a bit of adhesive remover for 2-3 minutes, and then scrape it out with an opening pick or one of the other tools in your kit. This can take quite a bit of work, so be patient. Mop up any remaining adhesive remover and give your MacBook Pro a few minutes to air dry. The replacement battery included in your iFixit kit comes with adhesive pre-installed. Test the battery's fit and alignment carefully before peeling off the film covering the adhesive, and then press each cell firmly into place. If any additional films/liners are present that weren't on your original battery, remove them now. Calibrate your new battery before using it: allow it to drain overnight, then charge it to 100% and drain it again until your MacBook Pro shuts down automatically. Charge it again and use it normally. If you notice any unusual behavior or problems after installing your new battery, you may need to [https://support.apple.com/en-gb/HT201295|reset your MacBook Pro's SMC|new_window=true].

'''do not''' wear contact lenses without eye protection .
protective gloves are also included in your kit . if you are concerned about skin irritation . put your gloves on now .

item.Text_raw: Now that your MacBook Pro is fully prepped, it's time to prep yourself. iFixit adhesive remover contains acetone, a mild skin and eye irritant. Wear eye protection when handling and applying the adhesive remover. (Eye protection is included in your kit.) '''Do not''' wear contact lenses without eye protection. Protective gloves are also included in your kit. If you are concerned about skin irritation, put your gloves on now.

item.Text: pull off the black rubber stopper from your bottle of adhesive remover .
twist to loosen or remove the bottle cap before you cut the applicator tip .
this unseals the bottle and allows the pressure to equalize before you cut the applicator tip . '''if you skip this step . the adhesive remover may spray out unexpectedly when the tip is cut . '''
use scissors to cut off the sealed tip of the applicator .
cutting close to the narrow tip will give you better control so you can apply the adhesive remover in small amounts .
twist and close the bottle cap securely before you proceed further .

item.Text_raw: Pull off the black rubber stopper from your bottle of adhesive remover. Twist to loosen or remove the bottle cap before you cut the applicator tip. This unseals the bottle and allows the pressure to equalize before you cut the applicator tip. '''If you skip this step, the adhesive remover may spray out unexpectedly when the tip is cut.''' Use scissors to cut off the sealed tip of the applicator. Cutting close to the narrow tip will give you better control so you can apply the adhesive remover in small amounts. Twist and close the bottle cap securely before you proceed further.

item.Text: apply a few drops of adhesive remover evenly under the edge of the leftmost battery cell .
you don't need to use very much . the small bottle contains more than twice the amount of solvent needed to remove all the battery cells .
wait 2-3 minutes for the liquid adhesive remover to penetrate underneath the battery cell before you proceed to the next step .

item.Text_raw: Apply a few drops of adhesive remover evenly under the edge of the leftmost battery cell. You don't need to use very much. The small bottle contains more than twice the amount of solvent needed to remove all the battery cells. Wait 2-3 minutes for the liquid adhesive remover to penetrate underneath the battery cell before you proceed to the next step.

item.Text: insert the flat edge of a spudger or plastic card underneath the leftmost battery cell .
run your tool along the bottom perimeter of the battery cell and lift to begin separating the adhesive .

item.Text_raw: Insert the flat edge of a spudger or plastic card underneath the leftmost battery cell. Run your tool along the bottom perimeter of the battery cell and lift to begin separating the adhesive.

item.Text: insert the spudger along the left-hand side of the leftmost battery cell .
run the spudger up along the left side of the leftmost battery cell .
slightly pry the leftmost battery cell to release it from the adhesive .

item.Text_raw: Insert the spudger along the left-hand side of the leftmost battery cell. Run the spudger up along the left side of the leftmost battery cell. Slightly pry the leftmost battery cell to release it from the adhesive.

item.Text: repeat the above steps to separate the adjacent battery cell from its adhesive .
apply a few drops of liquid adhesive remover under the battery cell .
wait 2-3 minutes for the adhesive remover to penetrate and soften the adhesive .
carefully wedge a spudger or plastic card inwards . being careful to not damage the battery . and separate the battery cell from the adhesive securing it to your macbook pro .

item.Text_raw: Repeat the above steps to separate the adjacent battery cell from its adhesive: Apply a few drops of liquid adhesive remover under the battery cell. Wait 2-3 minutes for the adhesive remover to penetrate and soften the adhesive. Carefully wedge a spudger or plastic card inwards, being careful to not damage the battery, and separate the battery cell from the adhesive securing it to your MacBook Pro.

item.Text: insert the flat end of a spudger underneath the larger leftmost battery cell .
carefully wedge the spudger inwards . being careful to not damage the battery cells .
pry the larger leftmost battery cell up off the upper case .

item.Text_raw: Insert the flat end of a spudger underneath the larger leftmost battery cell. Carefully wedge the spudger inwards, being careful to not damage the battery cells. Pry the larger leftmost battery cell up off the upper case.

item.Text: grasp the battery cells and gently move ( but do not remove ) them from their recess in the upper case .
leave the battery cells resting on top of the upper case as shown in the third picture .

item.Text_raw: Grasp the battery cells and gently move (but do not remove) them from their recess in the upper case. Leave the battery cells resting on top of the upper case as shown in the third picture.

item.Text: switch sides and repeat the above procedure for the two battery cells on the right-hand side of the macbook pro .
remember to add a small amount of liquid adhesive remover under each battery cell . and wait 2-3 minutes for it to penetrate before prying up the cell .
be careful not to puncture or otherwise damage the battery cells .

item.Text_raw: Switch sides and repeat the above procedure for the two battery cells on the right-hand side of the MacBook Pro. Remember to add a small amount of liquid adhesive remover under each battery cell, and wait 2-3 minutes for it to penetrate before prying up the cell. Be careful not to puncture or otherwise damage the battery cells.

item.Text: lift the battery as a whole up out of the upper case . and remove the battery .
before installing a new battery . remove all the old adhesive from the macbook pro's case .
with a little luck . you can slowly pull out each strip of adhesive with your fingers .

otherwise . soak each section of adhesive with a bit of adhesive remover for 2-3 minutes . and then scrape it out with an opening pick or one of the other tools in your kit . this can take quite a bit of work . so be patient .
mop up any remaining adhesive remover and give your macbook pro a few minutes to air dry .

the replacement battery included in your ifixit kit comes with adhesive pre-installed . test the battery's fit and alignment carefully before peeling off the film covering the adhesive . and then press each cell firmly into place . if any additional films/liners are present that weren't on your original battery . remove them now .

calibrate your new battery before using it . allow it to drain overnight . then charge it to 100 and drain it again until your macbook pro shuts down automatically . charge it again and use it normally .
if you notice any unusual behavior or problems after installing your new battery . you may need to your macbook pro's smc .

item.Text_raw: Lift the battery as a whole up out of the upper case, and remove the battery. Before installing a new battery, remove all the old adhesive from the MacBook Pro's case. With a little luck, you can slowly pull out each strip of adhesive with your fingers. Otherwise, soak each section of adhesive with a bit of adhesive remover for 2-3 minutes, and then scrape it out with an opening pick or one of the other tools in your kit. This can take quite a bit of work, so be patient. Mop up any remaining adhesive remover and give your MacBook Pro a few minutes to air dry. The replacement battery included in your iFixit kit comes with adhesive pre-installed. Test the battery's fit and alignment carefully before peeling off the film covering the adhesive, and then press each cell firmly into place. If any additional films/liners are present that weren't on your original battery, remove them now. Calibrate your new battery before using it: allow it to drain overnight, then charge it to 100% and drain it again until your MacBook Pro shuts down automatically. Charge it again and use it normally. If you notice any unusual behavior or problems after installing your new battery, you may need to [https://support.apple.com/en-gb/HT201295|reset your MacBook Pro's SMC|new_window=true].

item.Text: remove the following ten screws securing the lower case to the upper case .
two 2.3 mm pentalobe screws
eight 3.0 mm pentalobe screws
throughout this repair . track of each screw and make sure it goes back exactly where it came from to avoid damaging your device .

gently pull the lower case away from the upper case to remove it .

item.Text_raw: Wedge your fingers between the upper case and the lower case. Gently pull the lower case away from the upper case to remove it.

item.Text: the lower case is connected to the upper case with two plastic clips near its center .
during reassembly . gently push down the center of the lower case to reattach the two plastic clips .

item.Text_raw: The lower case is connected to the upper case with two plastic clips near its center. During reassembly, gently push down the center of the lower case to reattach the two plastic clips.

item.Text_raw: If necessary, remove the plastic cover adhered to the battery contact board.
